sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: is Euronews now. It's Tuesday, April 19. These are your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: A new phase of war. Russian forces launch a new offensive in the east of Ukraine after retreating from the capital region and other parts of the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Kyiv has vowed its forces will never give up.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: A busy day for US President Joe Biden. He will be addressing G7, EU and NATO leaders as the battle for Donbas begins.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And UK's Prime Minister Boris Johnson will face Parliament as it returns from Easter recess. He's expected to make a grovelling apology after he was fined for attending a party during lockdown.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Russia has launched a highly anticipated offensive along the entire front line in southern and eastern Ukraine in an attempt to secure the Donbass region. Their defense ministry has announced the destruction of a number of Ukrainian military facilities.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: A Ukraine military spokesperson says Russian forces are attempting to reach the administrative border of the Kersen region. In the Donetsk and Tavria directions, the Russian occupiers have intensified offensive operations along the entire line of contact. The main efforts of the enemy are focused on breaking through the defense of Ukrainian troops in Luhansk and Donetsk oblast, as well as establishing full control over the city of Mariupol.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Ukrainian troops say they are ready to counter a full-scale Russian offensive, with the country's defense ministry publishing footage of soldiers defending their positions in the government-controlled areas of Donetsk.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Recently, the Kremlin has declared the capture of the Donbass region was the main goal of the war, after fading to secure Kyiv.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov has told Indian media that Moscow is not targeting civilians during its invasion of Ukraine, despite growing evidence of human atrocities.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: As countries impose more sanctions on Russia over the war, an increasingly isolated Moscow is strengthening its relationships across Asia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: In the past few weeks, Lavrov has travelled to India and China. Well, our Euronews correspondent Galina Polonskaya joins me now. Hi, Galina. What else did Mr. Lavrov have to say in this press conference?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Hello, Charlotte. Well, Lavrov was asked if Russia was going to use nuclear weapons in Ukraine, and he said that Russia is going to use only conventional weapons at this stage. He said that the West played the president of Ukraine, Vladimir Zelensky, against Russia so that the Minsk agreements would never be applied. He also said that it was impossible to seriously discuss Mr. Zelenskyy proposals and accused him of constantly changing his mind. He mentioned the agreements that Ukraine gave to Russia in Istanbul written on the paper and said that they have been certainly changed. He denied the accusations of war crimes and said that it was the Ukrainian forces that were using civilians as human shield.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, this partnership building between Russia and India comes as everyday Russians start to feel the pinch of these sanctions imposed by the West.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Do we know if their stance has changed on this war almost two months in?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: Well, actually, a Kommersant newspaper has published a recent poll, and it still shows that the majority of Russians supports Vladimir Putin in his decision.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: But the question was, would you do something if you could have changed the past?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_19
sentences.sentence: So most of the people said no, and the tendency is that the level of support does not change either way but the real question what do russians really think is not answered i don't think that anyone really knows what to say independence sociologists say that what people are telling when they are answering the posters is what they are ready to say in public and that they are very confused and sometimes scared and sometimes just remember what they have heard on the state TV what is important and the social sociologists underline that is that both sides those who support and those who are against feel very very confused and scared and this is I think the truth about what russians feel at this point u.s president joe biden is to spearhead a video conference today with g7 leaders to discuss the latest developments in ukraine in a house full of leaders, NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg and EU Chief Ursula von der Leyen are also expected to be on the call.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_19
sentences.sentence: Top of the agenda for the virtual meeting will be the sending of heavy artillery such as tanks and jets, something Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has consistently called for from Western leaders. Such a debate is already heating up in Germany, with Germany's Chancellor Olaf Scholz coming under fire both domestically and internationally over his reluctance to commit Germany to sending more artillery.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_19
sentences.sentence: The meeting arrives at a pivotal moment in Russia's assault on Ukraine, as the Kremlin begins a large-scale offensive on Ukraine's eastern Donbass region.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_19
sentences.sentence: According to the White House, there are no plans for Biden to visit Kyiv, which may explain today's meeting being virtual.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_19
sentences.sentence: Instead, Washington is open to sending a top US official, such as Secretary of State Antony Blinken.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: While Ukraine continually asks the West for military support, around 100 Porsche-designed Leopard 1 tanks, 60 M113 mortar carriers, as well as bridge and pioneer tanks have been stored up in halls and tents in Flensburg, in the state of Schleswig-Holstein in Germany.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: They are all currently withdrawn from service, but would still be more than a useful addition to Ukraine's defence forces.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: This is the chancellery's fault.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Olaf Scholz is stepping on the brake and is thus putting a huge responsibility upon himself.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: He's not helping Ukraine in this matter and it would be easy for him to do so.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Olaf Scholz is coming under increasing pressure both from within and outside of Germany to authorise the delivery of heavy artillery in order to help Ukraine defend itself against Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Coalition partners accuse him of failing to live up to the promises he made in February, which was to relax Germany's restrictive stance on exporting weapons to conflict zones.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The chancellor has said that he wants to modernize the military, but support Ukraine at the same time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: This needs to be implemented.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Consequently, this cannot take forever within the administration, because the war is continuing and we have to move more quickly." But cabinet members feel their policy is in line with their current NATO partners.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: So far, there are two countries who have delivered armoured vehicles of Russian origin, that is Poland and Czech Republic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: All other NATO members have not done that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Should there be a policy shift, it has to be done jointly.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_21
sentences.sentence: But critics of Scholz say he is deliberating on a decision in an effort to appease those within his party who are still hoping for a diplomatic solution with the Kremlin. Mariupol. Medveduk's wife, Oksana Marchenko, also asked the Russian president to assist in her husband's exchange.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Russian press secretary Dmitry Peskov replied that if there was any reaction from Vladimir Putin, then authorities would report on it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, Russian television released a video in which captured British soldiers Sean Pinner, seen here, and Aidan Eslin appealed to Prime Minister Boris Johnson for help. They asked to be exchanged for Viktor Medvedchuk. According to the Ukrainian special services Medvedchuk who was put on the international wanted list trying to escape abroad. On April 12 the Ukrainian authorities announced his arrest. Later online Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy offered to exchange the Moscow supporter for captured Ukrainian soldiers. Should this swap happen, it wouldn't be the first during this war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Three weeks ago, Ukrainian and Russian forces conducted their first soldier-for-soldier exchange since Putin invaded Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_19
sentences.sentence: Israel says it fired a rocket into the Gaza Strip for the first time in months on Monday in retaliation after Palestinian militants fired their own rocket.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_19
sentences.sentence: The airstrike standoff follows escalations of clashes at a sensitive holy site in Jerusalem, a series of deadly attacks inside Israel and military raids across the occupied West Bank.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_19
sentences.sentence: South Africa's President, Cyril Ramaphosa, on Monday night declared a national state of emergency

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_19
sentences.sentence: after the worst floods in recorded history in the KwaZulu-Natal state.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_19
sentences.sentence: The President announced a three-pronged approach in how the government intends to deal with the disaster, focusing on immediate relief, recovery and rebuilding.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_19
sentences.sentence: Authorities have reported 443 deaths from the flooding so far.

sentences.sentence: You can stay up to date on these stories and more on our website at euronews.com.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: China has reported seven more deaths from COVID-19 a day after confirming its first fatalities from its current wave. There are concerns its stringent zero COVID policy could put the country's economy as well as the global supply chain at risk. A top Huawei executive warns this could trigger massive losses for the tech industry and tensions arising well to break this down for us is chief economist Alicia Garcia Aero from corporate banking company now Texas thanks for joining us from Hong Kong Alicia we know Shanghai has been in lockdown for almost a month now what disruptions are we seeing on the ground? Well, there are, of course, consumer-related disruptions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: So anything that is services, restoration, cinema, all of that is gone. And we are seeing that in the data already. Look at retail sales, you know, they're minus three. Restaurants, minus 18. I mean, it's just very bad. But what matters for global value chains is, of course, manufacturing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And we already have quite poor PMI data on manufacturing. Now we need to really see whether China is going to see a massive disruption in exports. We've not yet seen that, only imports so far. And the question is, will we see disruptions in exports in April?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: That would be really a worrisome trend for inflation in the world.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, speaking of that, many countries here in Europe have adopted a live with COVID policy to try and revive the economy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: What could happen to China's economy if another

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: city is plunged into lockdown?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: Well, we have more cities than Shanghai already. But the question is, will we have major cities like Guangdong or major manufacturing centers? I think China is trying very hard to avoid that through mass testing and other means. But we can't really guarantee that there will be no new lockdowns because the policy of dynamic zero COVID is still in place.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: What China can do in terms of policies is, of course, to ease liquidity.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: And we are seeing that. So the PBOC, People's's bank of china cut the reserve requirement ratio it's also basically transferring profits to the metro finance which is exactly the same as free free in more liquidity and the miniature finance has embarked in a big infrastructure plan but the problem is and this is different from Europe, that China doesn't really have an easy way to provide subsidies to households or SMEs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: So the impact on the economy, and especially on consumption and unemployment through SMEs, might be very large.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: And I don't think it's going to be easy to avoid it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: might be very large and I don't think it's going to be easy to avoid it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Boris Johnson faces Parliament later today for the first time after being fined for attending lockdown parties. Vincent McAvinny in London outlines what is in store for the British Prime Minister. It's been a week since Boris Johnson became the first Prime Minister in British history to be found to have broken the law by the police whilst in office over a party in June 2020 for his birthday which breached the lockdown rules that he himself had imposed on the public. There has been huge anger over this of course but he hasn't yet had to face politicians because parliament has been in its Easter recess. That changes today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: He's set to give an address in which he will likely repeat the apologies that he made last week on camera, but also he's going to try and divert attention, talking about his actions in Ukraine, traveling to meet President Zelensky, promising more weapons, and say that there are more pressing issues at play now compared to Partygate.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Now, some of his MPs are happy to go on board with that, but the opposition parties are all pretty livid. Now they intend to either today or tomorrow try to bring a vote of censure on the Prime Minister for misleading Parliament and his own MPs are having a meeting with him on Tuesday evening what's being dubbed a clear the air session in which he's going to try to build back support and build confidence in himself once again.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The problem looming over all of this, though, is that the prime minister could face another fine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: We know that the Met are planning to give out more fines for the investigations into the other events which took place.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And so that thread is constantly looming as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: It could be a drip drip, which the prime minister cannot predict.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: could be a drip-drip which the Prime Minister cannot predict. He'll have to face the Sakhir Starmer at PMQs tomorrow, before then somewhat escaping the heat by going to India for a prime ministerial visit.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Vincent McIverney, Euronews, London.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Welcome to the Cube.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Misinformation often spreads online during times of crisis and war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But it can also circulate during election campaigns when people are hungry for information and emotions are high.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And often it is presidential candidates who can find themselves at the centre of false claims.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So far, pro-Russian accounts online have seemingly focused their attention on the Ukraine war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But now they may also be turning their heads to the upcoming second round of voting in France's presidential election. A number of pro-Russian accounts on Telegram have been sharing this false claim and it's also appeared on Twitter. It falsely claims that Emmanuel Macron said that sanctions on Russia could result in an influx of 60 million refugees in the next 20 years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: You can see that a BBC News logo was also added to one such tweet.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But this claim is false.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: There is no such BBC report and Macron has not been recorded as saying anything like this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: What he has said in the past is that he wants European sanctions on Russia to go further and include Russia's energy sector.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: He also says that France should be prepared to welcome around 100,000 Ukrainian refugees given the war in their country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But he did not make any reference to up to 60 million refugees due to Russia sanctions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So that claim is false.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And it's perhaps not surprising, given that Macron's rival, Marine Le Pen, is the preferred presidential candidate of the Kremlin, given her previous close relationship with Moscow and Russian President Vladimir Putin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Le Pen's stance has somewhat hardened, but we're still seeing election misinformation continuing to spread, now focusing on those two candidates.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And it's also worth noting that Macron himself has said that election misinformation in countries like France is a serious threat to democracy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: If you want growth to be higher, please educate girls and empower women.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Those were the words of the IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva during a conversation with activist Malala Yousafzai on girls' education and gender equality.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_20
sentences.sentence: We have calculated that if women have the same access to the labour market as men, in the United States GDP would be 5% higher in Japan 9% higher in India 27% higher in Egypt 34% higher so you want to have prosperity make sure that women can contribute to their communities, to their societies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Activist Malala urged developed nations to continue and increase financing for education, focusing on girls.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: The world is facing a girls' education crisis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: There are 130 million girls out of school, and this is a figure that comes from before the pandemic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Now there are millions of more girls at risk of losing education because of the COVID-19 pandemic, but also climate change and conflicts.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Afghan women are some of those affected by a ban on girls' education after the Taliban swept back to power last August.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Since then, they have taken to the streets demanding the right to education Good morning.

sentences.sentence: How the children in Oklahoma City and indeed the children throughout America must be reacting to a horror of this magnitude.
